detail.data: D-I-A-G-R-A-M
Brief

A diagram is the result of understanding the thing being represented, it combines knowledge you have of the thing and procedure and how that can be effectively translated into a clear graphic representation. A diagram is achieved through the process of observation, reflection, understanding, documentation, iteration and experimentation. It is the synthesis of all of these attributes to make it meaningful and provide instruction. They appear deceptively simple but, as Johanna Drucker states, they are images that work hard!

So how does one arrive at a diagram? How does one simplify a complex procedure? How is it represented? How much information is required to communicate it? What graphic devices can be used or explored? How is movement translated into graphic form? Or duration? Or the stages of the activity? How does the audience interact with the diagram? What format or media best suits a diagram? Can a diagram work effectively in different cultures? Or without words? Can there be ambiguity within a diagram? These questions, and more, are to be explored, challenged and engaged with during the project.
Structure
1. Diagram as procedure

Daily we perform numerous activities, often complex multi staged procedures that require tools, sequencing, interaction, gesture, ordering, etc. These activities are often performed unconsciously, they have become a habit absorbed into our daily routine. Part 1 of the project is for you to closely observe how you do things and create a series of diagrams that present/represent these procedures.
2. Diagram as knowledge exchange

You will then exchange your diagram(s) within the group. Firstly you will perform or enact the diagram to usertest it, and provide a detailed review as to the effectiveness of it, its strengths and development opportunities. Secondly we will create a design pattern library of our various approaches to diagramming, for example; ways of presenting movement, duration, gesture or interaction. We will then refine our diagrams to utilise this shared pattern library.
3. Diagram as compendium

We will collaboratively create a publication that presents our various ways and approaches to diagramming. It will act as a toolkit for you to refer to when you need some help or insights in future times. We will produce this book as a group, and print, bind and distribute it amongst ourselves.
Research Examples

Bibliography

title: The very best of the voices in my head

detail.data: The very best of the voices in my head
This project was based around my personal experiences with mental health and the effect that had day to day, this is an extreme look at that, in the form of a personal diary.
Each page has an image of myself manipulated digitally with hand-written text adjacent.
The book has no back cover to allude to the fact that this is a continuing thing and that there may never be an end to the issues.
Clock²
This project was a challenge to test my problem solving and web development skills. I was tasked to create a clock in any way I liked, only requirement was to use p5.js.
The 168 analog clock faces form the digital time with the position of their hands creating the numbers and the dividing colon.
Live version available bellow, as well as the code.
ASCII Maze
This project is a 3D maze game built with babylon.js.
The maze is generated with the Recursive Backtracking algorithm in 2D, this is then used to form the walls of the maze. The start and end point are always in the same place but the path is generated.
Live version available bellow, as well as the code.
Unlocked Gallery
This project is a 3D WebGL based gallery built to host 50 students work for a self-lead FMP (Final Major Project) after my foundation course was ended early due to the coronavirus.

The spaces is based off the Boros Bunker in Berlin, our foundation class had taken a trip their a few weeks before starting this project. The work featured is students and tutors work and ranges from video, photography and 3D scans.

The space was designed in Blender, coded into the browser with Babylon.js and all the work has been converted to 'dxt.ktx' file format to reduce GPU memory usage, allowing it to be viewed on a low powered laptop.

I hosted a private view via zoom and we had over 300 visitors in the first month it was public. As well as being able to view our work, visitors were able to buy high quality copies of people's collections and all money raised went to a variety of Black Lives Matter charities.
Live version available bellow, as well as the code.
Absent Observation

This project originated from a response to a university brief around three shapes, Circle, Square and Triangle. I decided to take the breif further as a personal project, I create a new piece for this project every so often and so this will last as a continuing project.

Some of the pieces are based off of real spaces, others imagined by me. The whole premise is that it forces the audience to be an observer of a space that implies lonelines, this is represented through the plastic garden chair. The shop front scene that includes two chairs is the only one to have two, this is still inline with my thematic as the shop and thus the chairs are in the middle of nowhere.

Originally I had planned for these pieces to be displayed in a small format publication, I felt however, while discussing with peers it lacked the same feeling of observation that I had intended. I wanted the audience to have the eerie sense of looking through a window rather than say watching someone through social media for example. This publication enable people to hide what they were looking at.

I printed a few pieces large scale for the Open Studio at university. I had 160 GSM Matt prints at A1 size, the pieces came out perfectly as I had rendered them to exr format and used the CMYK colour space when editing the final renders in Photoshop.

Also for the Open Studio I created a baby that would 'observe' the audience, fitted with a webcam and servo motor I had a face detection system that would cause the baby's head to turn towards audience members. I went with a baby as I thought it embodied the idea of role models as if the baby was learning from the audience adding to the discomfort for the audience.
